metadata.sermon_title: Second Sunday of Easter: John 20:19–31 (and Job 38; 42:1–6)
metadata.sermon_start_end: The symbolism of night and darkness pervades the Gospel of John. At the very beginning we hear the proclamation that the light of the incarnate Word of God comes to shine in the darkness (1:5). Repeatedly in this gospel, Jesus teaches that he brings light to the world [...] The message of the resurrection is indeed too wonderful for us. Flesh and blood cannot inherit it. It is grasped only by faith. Through the Word of God the Holy Spirit creates such faith in those who gladly hear the message.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific passage, instead combining three distinct pericopes (Easter Day, 2nd Sunday, 3rd Sunday). This violates Dekker's rule that a sermon is exposition of 'one specific Bible passage'. It treats the Bible as a collection of themes (darkness, doubt, revelation) rather than recreating one specific text into a current word.
quotes: Today, the first Sunday after Easter Day, the story of 'Doubting Thomas' is always read.
Today's text comes from the very end of the book of Job.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one pericope and identify the unique element in that specific text that can be found nowhere else, rather than synthesizing multiple biblical books.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is basic awareness of Johannine symbolism (light/dark) and Jewish burial customs, but it lacks the depth of Hebrew/Greek linguistic analysis or the rigorous religious history Dekker demands. The exegesis remains at a literary-thematic level.
quotes: The master dramatist John tells us...
as is the burial custom of the Jews
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate specific exegetical insights from the original languages to uncover the 'nowhere else' quality of the text.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding human suffering (the Alabama tornado), which aligns with Dekker's demand for 'true truth' being concrete. However, it occasionally drifts into generalities about 'the death of a career' or 'the loss of youth'.
quotes: In 1994, a church in Piedmont, Alabama, was destroyed by a tornado...
the death of a friendship, the death of a career, the loss of youth
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid listing general categories of suffering; focus the application more sharply on the specific congregation's current zeitgeist.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a pattern of 'text then illustration'. While the Alabama story is powerful, it stands as a block of application following a block of exposition. The 'present of revelation' where text and hearer converge is interrupted by the jumps between three different biblical texts.
quotes: Thomas stands for all of us here... In 1994, a church in Piedmont...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Draw the hearer into the text itself so that the exposition of the Word is simultaneously the application to the hearer.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is strong on 'misery' (the darkness, the grave, the tornado). It avoids 'soft' misery. Redemption is correctly placed outside of man (Christ as the light). Gratitude is less explicitly developed but implied in the call to confession.
quotes: This is the night in which Sin and Death reign.
Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure the 'gratitude' (the life-changing humility) is more clearly linked to the Spirit's work in the hearer's specific life.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon mentions a 'real choice' between a man-made god and the biblical God, but the ultimate seriousness of being 'lost' (temporal or eternal) is muted. It leans toward a 'baffling' God rather than the urgency of the narrow way.
quotes: We have a real choice. We can choose a god who suits us...
This god will have no nail prints in his hands.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Thematize the possibility of being lost—either in time or eternity—as a consequence of the choice between the 'domesticated pet' god and the 'Lord and God'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes the two natures (the wounded man who is 'My Lord and my God') and insists on salvation coming from outside the self. This is the strongest part of the sermon.
quotes: It was not the sign of his glory that gave proof, but the sign of his sufferings.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'one Lord' to the specific 'misery' identified earlier to show how grace is the 'deepest of our life'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 2100 words, the sermon meets the 20-minute threshold. However, because it covers three different Sunday themes, the 'breadth' does not necessarily lead to 'depth' for a single passage.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Spend the 20+ minutes on one passage to achieve the 'depth' Miskotte and Dekker advocate.

overall_assessment.summary: The text provided is not a single sermon but a compilation of three distinct homiletical reflections. According to Dekker's theses, this fails the primary formal requirement of being an exposition of 'one specific Bible passage'. While the Christological focus is adequate and the acknowledgment of human misery is sharp, the lack of focus prevents the 'nowhere else' quality of a specific text from emerging. The application is concrete but the structure remains too thematic.
strengths: Strong Christocentric focus on the 'two natures' and Christ as the telos.
Adequate length to allow for theological development.
Refusal to offer 'soft' comfort, maintaining the reality of death and suffering.
weaknesses: Violation of the 'one specific passage' rule by merging multiple texts.
Lack of explicit 'two ways'/seriousness of being lost.
Exegesis remains thematic rather than linguistically or historically rigorous.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a collection of strong theological reflections, but it is not a 'sermon' in the strict sense of Dekker's definition. It functions more as a thematic speech about 'Easter' and 'Doubt' than an actualization of a specific written Word of God.
